content.description:
Climb the featured scoop in the right side of a small standalone boulder toward the right end of the field, starting standing with a good ledge.  Go up and over the overhanging point of the boulder.



A small, standalone boulder towards the right side of the field.  It's immediately down and left from a 20' vertical face.

Clean fall.

Climb the corner crack feature system at the left end of the wall.  To top out, move left across large blocks to let the little tree growing out of it keep fighting the good fight.



Behind and uphill from the boulder jumble that the Bear Bottom boulder has split out of is a 12-15' vertical wall split by a few cracks.  Bonsai is the corner crack on the left end of the wall.

Clean fall

Start as far to the left as you can and traverse the lip of the boulder to the arete on the far right, then mantle to top out.

For a silly variation, you can start from a bat-hang off the taller section in the middle of the boulder, and follow the remainder of the problem as normal.



Find the short boulders at the very bottom front of the field.  If you've found the Bear Bottom boulder, it's just a little further to the left/east of the area and down at ground level.

Clean fall.

Climb the excellent corner crack at the right end of the wall.



The right end of the wall behind the boulder jumble that the Bear Bottom boulder comes out of.

Clean enough fall.

Start squatting with a left hand in a sidepull and your right using a large ledge and an edge to its right as a pinch.  The route overlaps with Unknown on its right a bit, but avoid the large features on it.  Go straight up following a line of incuts in a small crack system and slopey pinches.  Trend right with the cracks towards the top.



Immediately left of Unknown.

Clean landing.

You no longer need to fly down to Squamish for a perfect layback flake.  Towards the left/east end of the boulder field, you'll see a distinct, flat, vertical face by itself.  The block that formed it by falling off makes for a perfectly flat landing area and sit start.  Start low and climb the layback flake.

It's certainly possible someone else already got the FA of this.  There's a route to its left that was definitely cleaned and it's just so obvious and great.



Towards the left end of the field, slightly down and to the right of the large, cracked slab that forms the end of the area.  There's one last, short face on the bottom level of the area to its left.

Clean landing.

Find the small cave on the right side of the Inch Worm boulder.  Start as far back on the lip rail as you can, climb out to the same point as with Inch Worm, and mantle up.



This is the right side of the Inch Worm boulder.

Short fall.

Start sitting and climb the right arete on the short face at the far left end of the area at ground level.  I found this clearly brushed and cleaned, so someone must've already put up the line.



The right arete of the last little face to the left of the area.

Mostly clean landing, but you need a spotter to keep you from hitting the little boulder behind the route.
The obvious small boulder field right across the road from the entrance to the parking lot.
